awd_titl_txt: Toward a Mechanotransduction Mimic of the Neural Stem Cell Niche
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, scientists have identified special regions of tissues -- known as niches -- within the human body that help sustain and rejuvenate it. These tissue regions contain specialized units called stem cells that provide new life and support to tissues as we grow and age. The stem cells reside locally within the tissues. The tissue acts like a parent to a child - it provides a nurturing environment to live. When the time is right, the environment signals the stem cells to move out and support the surrounding community. However, with disease or with aging, stem cells do not have the same survival or supportive response. It is not known how changes that occur in the stem cells' environment influences their response. In the brain, stem cells reside in a complex environment, directly interacting with other cells, blood vessels, and the surrounding matrix, each of which provides its own influence over the stem cells. The goal of this research is to understand how specific changes in the matrix environment alter the neural stem cell response. The results will be used to better inform how changes in the brain that occur with disease or aging can influence the neural stem cells. This would then allow for better design therapies to sustain stem cell support of the brain. Through both hands-on involvement and the analysis of images, engineering students, high school students, and middle school students will become more engaged in integrating the topics of mechanics, materials, and biomedicine through computer analysis and statistics involved with imaging. Student involvement in research is key to this engagement, and the PI will continue to have students of all ages supporting the research goals of the project. 

The overall goal of this research is to investigate the role of mechanotransduction in maintenance and neurogenesis of neural stem cells in order to identify the critical components involved with physiological changes to the neural stem cell niche.  It is hypothesized that stem cell maintenance and differentiation are instructed through mechanotransduction by the matrix and cells.  This hypothesis will be addressed through two aims.  First, by determining how engaging integrin receptors and mechanotransduction signaling pathway alter neural stem cell maintenance and neurogenesis.  Second, by determining how cadherin mechanotransduction alters the maintenance and neurogenesis of neural stem cells.  These aims will involve the use of microgel-based scaffolds that allow the decoupling of scaffold elasticity from peptide concentration, isolating changes in the mechanical environment from the biochemical environment.  Activation of integrins and cadherins will be characterized through various molecules that relate to the mechanocoupling between a cell and its environment or act as mechanical transducers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Inside the human brain reside special cells called stem cells. These stem cells are like master cells that can become many different cells in the brain. They are very sensitive to their surroundings and use signals from the nearby cells and materials to decide what to do next. These stem cells live in specific parts of the brain and are surrounded by other cells and substances that give them instructions and cues. The goal of this research was to learn more about this environment so that we can better control how the stem cells in the brain behave. In simpler words, we wanted to understand how to tell these special cells to do what we want them to do.

To perform this research, we made materials to mimic two different cell interactions: one with other cells, called cadherin interactions (Figure 1, right) and one with the surrounding material, called integrin interactions (Figure 1, left). We characterized these surfaces to determine their properties and to be able to quantify the interactions with the cells.

We wanted to see how stem cells behaved when they were exposed to different amounts of a protein called cadherin. We attached cadherin to a surface and recorded how stem cells interacted with it. We found that the more cadherin there was, the stronger the stem cells attached to the surface. This strong attachment changed the structure inside the stem cells. It created a network of proteins called F-actin, which is like the supporting structure of a building. This network allowed the stem cells to interact mechanically with their environment. Interestingly, when the stem cells interacted more with the surface, they started to change into neurons. This shows that the way stem cells attach to their surroundings can influence what type of cell they become. Overall, we uncovered that by controlling the amount of cadherin, we could control how stem cells develop into neurons. This result could be a valuable tool for growing neurons in the lab for research or medical purposes.

Next we wanted to understand how stem cells interact with a protein called laminin, which is found in the brain where stem cells live. We tested stem cells with laminin and a smaller piece of laminin called a peptide. We found that stem cells attached to both laminin and the peptide, but in different ways. When the stem cells attached to laminin, the cells used special connections called integrin interactions. These interactions helped the stem cells stay as stem cells and keep growing without changing into other types of cells. However, we blocked these integrin interactions, the stem cells started to change into a type of brain cell called an astrocyte. Astrocytes are important, but in this case, we preferred the stem cells to stay as stem cells. In summary, we discovered that the way stem cells attach to laminin is important for keeping them from changing into astrocytes. This finding could help develop new ways to control how stem cells behave in the brain.

The intellectual merit outcomes demonstrated that neural stem cells respond specifically to both cadherin and integrin interactions via mechanical pathways. These interactions led to uncovering interesting processes to regulate differentiation toward neurons and glial cells. The broader impacts of the work are both in the societal impact of the outcomes and the STEM workforce development through the research itself. Understanding how stem cells work within the brain provides new avenues to regulate these cells while also providing context for pathological changes that occur with disease, trauma, or aging. Importantly, this project had significant human resource development. This project supported three doctoral students and one was able to translate her skills to industry using an INTERN supplement. In addition, both capstone projects and REU opportunities were used to enhance undergraduate student training. Two different capstone projects were completed utilizing the basic research in the proposal, impacting 9 undergraduates in chemical engineering. Several other undergraduates were able to participate directly in the research through REU or other research project mechanisms for credit, work-study, or volunteering. During this project, we also exposed high school students to the research and STEM opportunities. The doctoral students were mentors to 2 students within the Young Scholars Program, which places high school students in research labs for 6 weeks in the summer. The project provided a number of opportunities for future scientists and engineers to apply research and support their STEM career development, broadening participation in engineering research.

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Rebecca K Willits
